document: The Relational Model explains how data is organized in relational databases using relations, schemas, tuples, attributes, domains, and integrity constraints such as key, entity, and referential integrity.

questions.question: A relational database is defined as a set of relations.
In the relational model, rows are formally called attributes.
The schema of a relation describes the structure and data types of its attributes.
The cardinality of a relation refers to the number of attributes.
A domain defines the set of valid values for an attribute.
Tuples in a relation are considered ordered.
All tuples in a relation must be distinct.
A key is an attribute or set of attributes that uniquely identifies a tuple.
Every superkey is a candidate key.
A primary key is selected from the set of candidate keys.
Primary key attributes are allowed to have NULL values.
Entity integrity ensures that primary key values are not NULL.
A foreign key references the primary key of another relation.
Referential integrity allows foreign key values that do not exist in the referenced table.
Domain constraints ensure attribute values come from a predefined set of valid values.
The DROP TABLE command removes only the data but keeps the table schema.
ALTER TABLE can be used to add a new attribute to an existing relation.
A view stores data physically in the database.
CASCADE in referential integrity propagates changes to related tuples.
The relational database state represents the current contents of all relations.
